instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in the related study for discriminating detailed forest alliances in a Mediterranean-climate landscape?
Output:
The metric chosen in the study was overall accuracy (OA), which measures the percentage of correctly classified pixels in relation to the total number of pixels. This metric evaluates the performance of the classification algorithm in accurately identifying different forest alliances.

In terms of how far this metric can go, the study found that using multi-seasonal multispectral satellite data, specifically from the Sentinel-2 (S2) satellites, resulted in significantly improved overall accuracy for both Level 1 tree/no tree classifications and Level 2 forest alliances. The S2 variables had 0.4-2.1% higher OA for Level 1 classifications and 5.1-11.8% higher OA for Level 2 classifications compared to the Landsat 8 (L8) variables.

Furthermore, the study compared the accuracy of the S2-based classification to a classification based on simulated hyperspectral satellite data (HyspIRI). The S2-based classification had an overall accuracy of 74.3% (Kappa = 0.70), which was only 1.6% lower than the best HyspIRI-based classification. This suggests that the S2 spectral-temporal data has a strong capability for mapping global forest alliances or similar detailed floristic associations at medium spatial resolutions

instruction: How did the study compare the accuracy of classifications between different variables and satellite platforms for discriminating detailed forest alliances in a Mediterranean-climate landscape?
Output: The study compared the accuracy of classifications between different variables and satellite platforms by using real and simulated Sentinel-2 (S2) and Landsat 8 (L8) data. The Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier was used for hierarchical classification of land-cover and forest alliances. The study evaluated the relative benefits of single- and multi-seasonal multispectral satellite data. Both real and simulated multi-seasonal multispectral variables significantly improved overall accuracy (OA) for tree/no tree classifications and forest alliances. Classifiers with S2 variables were generally more accurate than L8 variables, with S2 having higher OA than L8 for both tree/no tree and forest alliances classifications. Combining multispectral bands and indices or using just bands was found to be more accurate than relying on just indices for classification. Simulated hyperspectral satellite data (HyspIRI) from past research had significantly greater accuracy than real S2 and L8 variables. The final alliance-level map used simulated multi-seasonal S2 bands and indices, which had an overall accuracy of 74.3%. The accuracy of this classification was only 1.6% significantly lower than the best HyspIRI-based classification.
